Because it is the basis for the benefit and peace of all beings, and because it proclaims the vast and profound Dharma.

To whom are the dharmas included in these three piá¹­akas directed?
They are directed to the mental factors and mental activities that are accomplished through hearing, thinking, and cultivation.
As a scripture says:
All minds and mental factors have an object, have a mode of activity, have a basis, and are associated.
What is the object of those [minds and mental factors] in regard to this dharma?
It is the sutras, etc.
What is their mode of activity?
It is the characteristics of the aggregates, etc., and their corresponding meanings.
What is their basis?
It is the understanding and memory of others' expressions and habitual tendencies.
What is their association?
It is mutually assisting each other, with equal understanding of the object and mode of activity.
What is the distinction of objects in regard to the Dharma?
In brief, it is fourfold: objects as universal, objects as purification of the bodhisattva practices, objects as skill in liberative art, and objects as purification of the obstacle of action.

Objects as universal are also fourfold: objects as images with conceptual constructions, objects as images without conceptual constructions, objects as the limit of existence, and objects as the accomplishment of the task.
Objects as images with conceptual constructions are the objects of meditation and insight that are accompanied by the will.

Objects as images without conceptual constructions are the objects of meditation and insight that are not accompanied by the will.ğŸ”½Objects as the limit of existence are all things as they are in their totality and as they are in their particularity.
All things as they are in their totality are the aggregates, the sense spheres, and the sense bases.

As for the nature of things as they are, it refers to the sixteen aspects of the four noble truths, such as the suchness of all conditioned things being impermanent, all conditioned things being suffering, all dharmas being without self, nirvana being tranquil, emptiness, wishlessness, and signlessness.
As for the object of support for accomplishing what is to be done, it refers to the transformation of the basis, and this transformation of the basis is inconceivable.
Among the sixteen aspects, how many aspects are included in emptiness?
It refers to two.
How many aspects are included in wishlessness?
It refers to six.
How many aspects are included in signlessness?
It refers to eight.

There are also five kinds of objects of support for purifying practice, namely, for those with much greed, the object of support is the impure; for those with much anger, the object of support is the cultivation of loving-kindness; for those with much delusion, the object of support is the conditioned arising of various conditions; for those with pride, the object of support is the distinction of realms; for those with discursive thoughts, the object of support is the mindfulness of inhalation and exhalation.

The skillful objects are also of five kinds, namely, the skill in the aggregates, the skill in the elements, the skill in the sense bases, the skill in dependent origination, and the skill in what is possible and impossible.
How should one contemplate the skill in what is possible and impossible?
One should contemplate it as the skill in dependent origination.
What is the difference between the skill in what is possible and impossible and the skill in dependent origination?
If it is that dharmas moisten other dharmas, causing them to be apart from causelessness and unequal causes, this is the skill in dependent origination;
If cause and effect correspond to each other, and there is acceptance and birth, this is the skill in what is possible and impossible.

The objects for purifying defilements are the coarseness of the lower stages, the calmness of the higher stages, suchness, and the four noble truths. These are called the objects for purifying defilements.
If one wishes to diligently and carefully contemplate dharmas, by how many principles can one correctly contemplate?
By four principles, namely, the principle of dependence, the principle of function, the principle of proof, and the principle of the way things are.
What is the principle of dependence?
It means that when dharmas arise, they must depend on various conditions.
What is the principle of function?
It means that dharmas with different characteristics each have their own function.
What is the principle of proof?
It means to speak words that are not contradictory to the various means of valid cognition in order to prove what should be accomplished.
What is the principle of the way things are?
It means that from beginningless time, in the dharmas that abide in their own characteristics and common characteristics, there are accomplishments, the nature of dharmas, and the way things are.
Correctly contemplating the dharmas, how does one give rise to investigation of the dharmas?
It means giving rise to four kinds of investigation:
1. Investigation of names, 2. Investigation of objects, 3. Investigation of the provisional establishment of self-natures, 4. Investigation of the provisional establishment of distinctions.
What is investigation of names?
It means seeking out the characteristics of the collections of names, phrases, and syllables, all of which are not truly established.
What is investigation of objects?
It means investigating the characteristics of the aggregates, realms, and sense bases of all dharmas and finding them to be unreal.
What is the investigation of the postulation of self-nature?
It means investigating the correspondence between the names and meanings of all dharmas and finding that the self-nature is only the causal nature of the nominal expressions.
What is the investigation of the postulation of distinctions?
It means investigating the correspondence between the names and meanings of all dharmas and finding that the distinctions are only the causal nature of the nominal expressions.
Having cultivated the investigation of dharmas with right effort, how does one give rise to the wisdom of suchness regarding dharmas?
It means giving rise to four kinds of wisdom of suchness:

1. The wisdom of suchness induced by the investigation of names, 2. The wisdom of suchness induced by the investigation of phenomena, 3. The wisdom of suchness induced by the investigation of the postulation of self-nature, 4. The wisdom of suchness induced by the investigation of the postulation of distinctions.
What is the wisdom of suchness induced by the investigation of names?
It means the wisdom of realizing that names are unobtainable.
What is the wisdom of suchness induced by the investigation of phenomena?
It is the cognition that knows that even the characteristics of phenomena cannot be apprehended.
What is the cognition of reality that is induced by the investigation of the designation of self-nature?
It is the cognition that knows that the self-nature that really exists cannot be apprehended.
What is the cognition of reality that is induced by the investigation of the designation of distinctions?
It is the cognition that knows that the distinctions that really exist cannot be apprehended.
How should one know the yoga stage of one who diligently cultivates samÄdhi based on the Dharma?

What is the support?
It refers to one who has already accumulated the requisites for enlightenment, who has the heat and other stages, and who has heard much about the noble truths.
What is the function?
It refers to the proper mental attention that takes this as its object.
What is the mirror?
It refers to the samÄdhi that has characteristics and takes the object as its object.
What is the clarity?
It refers to the cognition that does not apprehend the grasper and the grasped.
Based on this principle, the Buddha, the Blessed One, has wonderfully and well proclaimed:
The bodhisattva, in meditative concentration, observes that images are only mind.
When the conceptualization of meaning is eliminated, he carefully observes that it is only his own conceptualization.
In this way, abiding in his own mind, he knows that the grasped does not exist.
Next, the grasper is also non-existent, and finally he touches the attainment of nothing to grasp.
What is the basis?
It refers to the transformation of the basis.
Because one abandons all coarseness and attains the pure transformation of the basis.
Among all dharmas, what is skill in dharmas?
It refers to being well-versed.
What is skill in meaning?
It refers to being well-versed in the characteristics of Abhidharma and Vinaya.
What is skill in words?
It refers to being well-versed in the interpretation of words.
What is skill in speech?
It refers to being well-versed in the worldly expressions such as I and mine, and speaking in accordance with them without deep attachment.
What is skill in the secret meaning of the past and future?
It means being able to know well the acceptance of the past and the liberation of the future.
How does one abide in the Dharma among all dharmas?
If one does not attain the wisdom of cultivation but only diligently practices hearing and contemplation, it is not called abiding in the Dharma.
If one does not attain hearing and contemplation but only diligently practices the wisdom of cultivation, it is also not called abiding in the Dharma.
If one attains both kinds of skillful means and abides in them, it is called abiding in the Dharma.
If one only upholds and recites the Dharma, expounds it for others, and contemplates its meaning, this is called hearing and contemplation.
If one is not content with the skillful means of cultivating samÄdhi, this is called the wisdom of cultivation.
The skillful means of samÄdhi refers to uninterrupted, earnest skillful means and unmistaken skillful means.

Because it is vast and profound in terms of the nature of omniscience.

Because they are far removed from the nature of the Dharma, have not planted good roots, and are embraced by bad friends.

As explained in the Vaipulya section:

Based on what secret meaning is this said?
It means that there is no intrinsic nature, no intrinsic substance, no abiding in one's own substance, and no nature and characteristics as grasped by foolish common people.

There are seven kinds, corresponding to the differences among individuals who are dominated by craving, hatred, delusion, pride, discursive thought, a mixture of defilements, or a small amount of defilements.

There are three kinds, corresponding to the differences among individuals who belong to the vehicle of the word hearers, the vehicle of the solitary enlightened ones, and the Mahayana.

How is it distinguished by realms?
It is said: ordinary beings, learners, and adepts in the desire realm.

There are also bodhisattvas in the desire and form realms, and there are also pratyekabuddhas and inconceivable tathÄgatas in the desire realm, due to the distinctions in the characteristics of individuals.
What are the distinctions in practice?
In brief, there are five types:

1. Bodhisattvas of resolute practice, 2. Bodhisattvas of superior intention practice, 3. Bodhisattvas of conceptual practice, 4. Bodhisattvas of signless practice, and 5. Bodhisattvas of effortless practice, due to the distinctions in the characteristics of individuals.
What is an individual who is dominated by craving?
It refers to one with intense and long-lasting craving.
Similarly, individuals who are dominated by anger, delusion, pride, and discursive thought all have the distinctions of intensity and duration.
What is an individual who is of average faculties?
It refers to one who abides in a state of natural afflictions.

It refers to one who abides in a state of naturally weak afflictions.

They seek liberation for themselves, make vast and correct vows, cultivate detachment and renunciation, and have the intention of attaining enlightenment by themselves. What are the individuals of the Great Vehicle?

For the sake of liberation for all beings, they give rise to vast and correct vows, cultivate the intention for the nirvÄá¹‡a that is not a resting place, take the bodhisattva canon as their object, diligently practice the Dharma that accords with the Dharma, mature beings and cultivate the Buddha lands, receive the great prediction, and realize unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
What are the individuals who have not yet accumulated provisions?

They are those who take as their object the dharmas that are the dominant conditions for the truths, give rise to the soft stage of pure faith and understanding, accomplish the soft stage of the factors conducive to liberation, and have not yet determined the time of birth.
What are the individuals who have accumulated some but not all provisions?

That is, taking the supreme dharmas of the truths as objects, one gives rise to middling pure faith and understanding, and when one has accomplished the middling factors conducive to liberation, one is definitely born in the next life.
What is a person who has already fully accumulated the requisites?

That is, taking the supreme dharmas of the truths as objects, one gives rise to superior pure faith and understanding, and when one has accomplished the superior factors conducive to liberation, one is born in this very life.

Moreover, one who has not yet fully accumulated the requisites is one who, taking the supreme dharmas of the truths as objects, accomplishes the inferior receptivity to the discernment of dharmas with regard to the truths, and accomplishes the inferior factors conducive to penetration, but is not yet definitely born.
What is a person who has already fully accumulated the requisites and one who has not yet fully accumulated the requisites?

That is, taking the supreme dharmas of the truths as objects, one accomplishes the middling receptivity to the discernment of dharmas with regard to the truths, and accomplishes the middling factors conducive to penetration, and is definitely born in the next life.

Those who have already completed the equipment are those who take the supreme dharmas of the truths as objects. They have already perfected the supreme patience that investigates dharmas with regard to the truths and have already perfected the supreme aids to penetration. When these aids to penetration arise,
among them, the three grades of aids to penetration are those that exclude the supreme worldly dharmas.

Because the nature of the supreme worldly dharmas is only one instant and they definitely do not continue. When they arise, one definitely enters into the clear realization of the truths and not the previous stage.

There is the meaning of retrogression from the lower and middling grades of the aids to liberation and the aids to penetration. This is only retrogression from the actual practice and not from the propensities, because those who have already relied on nirvÄá¹‡a and first generated the roots of good will not again newly generate them.
What is a person who follows faith?
It is one who has already completed the equipment and whose nature is that of dull faculties, who follows the teachings of others and cultivates the clear realization of the truths.
What is a person who follows the teachings?
It means that the equipment is already complete, and the nature is sharp faculties, naturally in accordance with the supreme principle of the truths, cultivating the insight into the truths.
What kind of person is a faith-follower?
It means one who has already reached the stage of fruition in following faith.
What kind of person is a view-attainer?
It means one who has already reached the stage of fruition in following the Dharma.
What kind of person is a body-witness?
It means those still in training who have already fully attained the eight liberations.
What kind of person is a wisdom-liberated one?
It means one who has already exhausted the defilements but has not yet fully attained the eight liberations.
What kind of person is a both-ways-liberated one?
It means one who has already exhausted the defilements and has fully attained the eight liberations.
What kind of person is a stream-enterer?
It means one who abides in the stage of determining the truth, and one who abides in the fifteen moments of the path of seeing.
What kind of person is a stream-enterer?
It means one who abides in the sixteenth moment of the path of seeing.
This path of insight is also called the stage of right and definite judgment, and also called the clear realization of the truths.
If one who has not yet freed the desire realm from desire enters the stage of right and definite judgment, he attains the fruit of stream-winner.
If one who has doubled his freedom from desire of the desire realm enters the stage of right and definite judgment, he attains the fruit of once-returner.
If one who has already freed the desire realm from desire enters the stage of right and definite judgment, he attains the fruit of non-returner.

If one has already eternally eliminated all the passions eliminated by the path of insight and attained the fruit of stream-winner, why is it said that one attains the fruit of stream-winner by eternally eliminating the three bonds?
Because of their preeminence.
Why are they preeminent?

Because they are the cause of not setting out for liberation, because even though one has set out, they are again the cause of false deliverance, and because they are the cause of incorrect deliverance.
Also, these three bonds are the cause of confusion about the object of knowledge, the cause of confusion about views, and the cause of confusion about the antidote.
What is a person who is a candidate for the fruit of once-returning?
It is a person who, in the path of cultivation, has already abandoned the five categories of defilements of the desire realm and abides in that path.
What is a person who is a once-returner?
It is a person who, in the path of cultivation, has already abandoned the sixth category of defilements of the desire realm and abides in that path.
What is a person who is a candidate for the fruit of non-returning?
It is a person who, in the path of cultivation, has already abandoned the seventh and eighth categories of defilements of the desire realm and abides in that path.
What is a person who is a non-returner?
It is a person who, in the path of cultivation, has already abandoned the ninth category of defilements of the desire realm and abides in that path.

If one has already permanently abandoned all the defilements that are to be abandoned by the path of seeing, and has also permanently abandoned all the defilements of the desire realm that are to be abandoned by the path of cultivation, and has attained the fruit of non-returning, why is it said that one attains the fruit of non-returning by permanently abandoning the five lower fetters?
Because it is the most excellent.
Why is it the most excellent?
Because it is the supreme cause for the lower realms and the lower realms.
What is a person who is a candidate for the fruit of arhatship?
It means one who has permanently severed the eighth affliction of the peak of existence and abides in that path.
What is a person who is a fruit of arhatship?
It means one who has permanently severed the ninth affliction of the peak of existence and abides in that final path.
If an arhat permanently severs all afflictions of the three realms, why is it said that by permanently severing the five higher fetters one attains the fruit of arhatship?
Because it is the most excellent.
Why is it most excellent?
Because it is the cause for taking the higher realms and the cause for not abandoning the higher realms.
What is a person who is subject to seven existences at most?
It means one who is a stream-enterer, who transmigrates through the heavens and the human realm, and experiences a mixture of births, and attains the end of suffering after at most seven existences.
What is a person who goes from family to family?
It means one who is a stream-enterer, who attains the end of suffering by going from family to family either in the heavens or among humans.
What is a person who is a once-returner?
